intro.title: 🚀 Mindset & Tech Adventure
intro.description: Develop both your mindset and technical skills through hilarious and interactive challenges
intro.subtitle: Train your brain and your code skills while laughing through the pain

phases.title: Mindset Basics
phases.intro: Test your understanding of growth vs. fixed mindset principles with realistic and funny situations.
phases.description: Dive into the foundations of a growth mindset: how to embrace challenges, reframe setbacks, and view effort as a path to mastery.
phases.scenario: Your app just crashed minutes before a demo. Panic? Blame the intern? Or... channel your inner growth warrior?

questions.question: How would you reframe: "I'm not good at this"?

options.A: I'm not good yet ‚Äî but I can learn
options.C: I'll ask someone to do it for me
options.D: Maybe I'll be a poet instead

questions.explanation: Growth mindset is reflected in: 'I'm not good yet ‚Äî but I can learn.'

questions.question: Your code fails 3 times in a row. You think:

options.A: Each failure teaches me what doesn't work
options.B: I'm just not cut out for coding

questions.explanation: Failures are stepping stones, not stop signs.

questions.question: A colleague solves a problem faster than you. You:

options.A: Ask them to explain their approach
options.C: Pretend you knew the answer all along

questions.explanation: Learning from others accelerates growth.

questions.question: When facing a difficult bug, you:

options.A: Break it down into smaller testable parts
options.C: Wait for someone else to fix it

questions.explanation: Systematic problem-solving beats frustration.

questions.question: After negative feedback on your code, you:

options.B: Assume the reviewer is being mean
options.D: Secretly critique their code in revenge

questions.explanation: Constructive criticism is fuel for growth.

questions.question: When stuck on a problem for hours, you:

options.A: Take a break and return with fresh eyes
options.B: Keep banging your head against it

questions.explanation: Stepping away often provides new perspectives.

questions.question: A new technology is required for a project. You:

options.A: Dive into docs and build a small prototype
options.B: Say you already know it (then panic)
options.D: Claim the tech is just a fad

questions.explanation: Comfort with learning beats fake expertise.

questions.question: Your pull request gets rejected. You:
questions.explanation: Code reviews are learning opportunities.

questions.question: When pair programming with someone more skilled, you:

options.B: Let them do all the work
options.C: Pretend to understand when you don't

questions.explanation: Collaboration beats competition for growth.

questions.question: After solving a tough problem, you:

options.A: Document the solution for future reference
options.B: Quickly move to the next task
options.C: Brag about how easy it was
options.D: Hope you never see it again

questions.explanation: Reflection solidifies learning.

phases.title: Web Technologies
phases.intro: Flex your frontend and backend basics
phases.description: You'll cover HTML, CSS, JS, frameworks, and how to avoid breaking everything with one div.
phases.scenario: You deployed the homepage. It works on your machine. On everyone else's? A blank screen of doom.

questions.question: Your CSS isn't applying. First you:

options.A: Check browser dev tools for errors

questions.explanation: Dev tools reveal CSS application issues.

questions.question: JavaScript throws 'undefined is not a function'. You:
questions.explanation: This usually indicates calling a non-existent method.

questions.question: The page renders differently in Firefox. You:

options.A: Check for unsupported features on caniuse.com

questions.explanation: Cross-browser testing prevents surprises.

questions.question: Your React component won't update. You:
questions.explanation: State management issues often cause update problems.

questions.question: The API returns 500 errors. You:

options.A: Check network tab for response details
options.D: Mock the data and pretend it's fine

questions.explanation: Server errors require examining the actual response.

questions.question: Your flexbox layout breaks in IE11. You:
questions.explanation: IE has specific flexbox implementation quirks.

questions.question: The page flashes unstyled content. You:
questions.explanation: FOUC indicates CSS loading timing issues.

questions.question: Your media queries aren't working. You:
questions.explanation: Missing viewport tag breaks responsive design.

questions.question: The JavaScript bundle is too large. You:

options.B: Tell users to get better internet

questions.explanation: Bundle analysis reveals optimization opportunities.

questions.question: The CSS animations are janky. You:
questions.explanation: Hardware acceleration improves animation performance.

phases.title: üïµÔ∏è Scraper's Detective Agency
phases.description: Learn to crawl data without being crawled by guilt or firewalls.
phases.scenario: Your scraper got blocked. Do you switch IPs, add delay, or send the website cookies?

questions.question: You get HTTP 429 (Too Many Requests). You:
questions.explanation: Backoff shows respect for server resources.

questions.question: The site uses Cloudflare protection. You:

options.B: Use headless Chrome with stealth plugins

questions.explanation: Understanding protections helps craft ethical solutions.

questions.question: CAPTCHAs appear after 5 requests. You:

options.D: Train a neural network to solve them

questions.explanation: Human-like behavior reduces bot detection.

questions.question: Data loads via JavaScript. You:

options.A: Use Puppeteer to render the page
options.B: Find XHR endpoints in dev tools
options.C: Ask the site for an API

questions.explanation: Headless browsers execute JS like real users.

questions.question: The site changes its HTML weekly. You:

options.A: Build resilient selectors using data attributes

questions.explanation: Stable selectors prevent frequent breakage.

questions.question: You need to scrape 100,000 pages. You:

options.A: Implement distributed queueing with rate limits

questions.explanation: Distributed systems require careful coordination.

questions.question: The site blocks your IP range. You:
questions.explanation: Residential IPs appear as regular users.

questions.question: Data appears after button clicks. You:
questions.explanation: Proper event triggering mimics user behavior.

questions.question: The site requires login. You:

options.A: Check if a public API exists first

questions.explanation: Always prefer authorized access methods.

questions.question: You accidentally DDoS a small site. You:
questions.explanation: Ethical scraping includes damage control.

phases.title: Change is Inevitable. So is Crying.
phases.intro: Learn to survive shifting requirements and emotional damage
phases.description: Nothing is final. Clients change their minds. PMs forget what they said. You adapt.
phases.scenario: You just finished the feature. The PM says, 'Actually, we decided to pivot.'

questions.question: Best reaction to last-minute changes:

options.B: Update the Jira ticket and ask clarifying questions

questions.explanation: Be the calm in the feature-storm.

options.B: Update the Jira ticket and ask clarifying questions

questions.explanation: Be the calm in the feature-storm.

phases.title: Technical Problem Solving
phases.intro: Get serious about fixing bugs (but with memes)
phases.description: Bug fixing is like therapy: dig deep, be patient, and sometimes it’s your fault.
phases.scenario: 500 errors all over production. You have no logs. Do you panic or debug like a ninja?

questions.question: Bug only happens at midnight. You:

options.C: Ignore it and blame the timezone

questions.explanation: If you can't reproduce it, you can't fix it.

phases.title: The Daily Standup Circus
phases.intro: Learn to sound productive before coffee
phases.description: Standups are performance art. Learn how to summarize chaos in 30 seconds.
phases.scenario: You forgot what you did yesterday. Do you admit it, invent tasks, or say 'blocked by dependencies'?

questions.question: Best standup trick:
questions.explanation: It’s not lying—it’s agile improv.

phases.title: The Bug Bounty Showdown
phases.intro: Hunt bugs like a bounty hunter with caffeine issues
phases.description: Every bug you find might be worth $500—or your weekend.
phases.scenario: Your teammate finds 10 bugs before you even wake up. Will you catch up or sabotage their Wi-Fi?

questions.question: A bug gives access to user data. You:

options.C: Use it to prank your PM

questions.explanation: Ethical hacking = responsible disclosure.

phases.title: Database Diner: Order Up!
phases.intro: Order, normalize, and serve your data hot
phases.description: Design schemas like a gourmet chef: organized, delicious, and no duplicates allowed.
phases.scenario: Your client’s data is a spreadsheet with 800 columns. You must normalize it before it normalizes you.

questions.question: What’s 3rd Normal Form?

options.B: A way to eliminate transitive dependencies

questions.explanation: 3NF = reduce redundancy and dependency on non-key attributes.

phases.title: ️ Mindset Gym: No Pain, No Brain
phases.intro: Build your mental reps like a brain athlete
phases.description: Mindset isn’t magic. It’s repetition, struggle, and belief that your brain can do pushups too.
phases.scenario: You failed 3 coding interviews in a week. Do you keep going or start that bakery you always dreamed of?

questions.question: You failed your dream job interview. You:

options.D: Move to a cabin and write a blog

questions.explanation: Rejection is redirection (with better practice).
